text: anger and frustration on the streets of
Turkey
thousands of Kurds marched across the
country including the capital and
Istanbul some protestors launched
fireworks at police the response rubber
bullets and tear gas they are furious
that Turkey seems to be standing by as
Islamic state advances on the Syrian
town of kobani
they say Turkey's failure to help the
Kurdish fighters there will lead to its
fall several were killed in the clashes
earlier hundreds of Kurds cut and jumped
the fence along the border saying they
want to fight alongside their Syrian
cousins Turkey's president has admitted
kobani is in peril but says only a
coordinated ground operation can save
the city
he's not prepared to act alone I'm
telling the West dropping bombs will not
provide a solution the terror will not
be over unless we cooperate on a ground
operation here in kobani coalition
warplanes launched another round of air
strikes again and again hitting jihadi
targets it didn't stop the fighting but
the strike seems to have halted the
advance of biiss fighters at least for
now Canada is the latest country to join
the coalition launching airstrikes but
the u.s. admitted more is needed
airstrikes alone are not going to be
enough anywhere not just in Iraq or not
just in Iraq but also in Syria and
certainly around kobani to be a tipping
point they can put pressure they can
help disrupt and degrade their
capabilities around kobani but
ultimately it's going to take more than
just airstrikes
to try to preserve it or frankly any
territory that ISIL wants to possess
from a distance
anxious Turkish Kurds look on they too
doubts that a strikes can really save
kobani Laura Westbrook BBC news
